content.description:
Start as for

Attacking Hawk

, but go straight up into the crack system. You can clip the first bolt on

AH

or place a finger-sized cam in an undercling feature. Lace up the wavy crack before moving onto the mini-ledge. Sit down rest, compose yourself, and climb into the first crux moving through the awesome diagonal crack. Rest up below the roof, then perform some funk. Take a deep breath, keep your head, and enjoy the beautiful upper dihedral. It's rare to find lines like this in the Poudre that go on only gear, so this one was a treat to climb!
content.protection: Micro- and finger-sized cams, optional 1-2 small/medium stoppers, and 1 large stopper.
content.location:
It immediately to the right of

Attacking Hawk

.

content.description: 5.11ish climbing leads to a brutal roof crux that may involve kneebars and a desperate reach over the roof. It is probably in the 13+/14- range. This might need an additional bolt or two and is a closed project for now, as far as I know, but talk to the equipper if you would like to try it.
content.location:
Marked by a permadraw in the roof, this is just to the right of

Grey Havens

.

content.description:
This is the namesake route that you probably hiked up here for. Once standing underneath the wall, it just begs to be climbed. It has excellent movement on unique rock. Easily one of the best routes of the grade in the Poudre, this one gets all the stars in my book, which may not be saying much. Come try it, and you decide!

There are essentially four distinct sections with two good rests. Start with an interesting boulder problem traversing along the mini-arete, and immediately fire into compression climbing on the wing feature, culminating in an airy traverse to the rest underneath the roof. Pull the roof into the finger crack on sweet locks leading to another rest before performing the final thin and balancy redpoint crux. Enjoy easier climbing and swirly rock to the anchor.
content.location: It is in the dead center of the wall.
